question: How is the conflict and relationship between Don Carlo and Brindle Bill portrayed in the novel 'Pen Pictures'? Please explain how Don Carlo defied and fought Brindle Bill, leading to his identification as the Hero of Shirt-Tail Bend.
gold_answer: Don Carlo defied and fought Brindle Bill, and was identified as the Hero of Shirt-Tail Bend.
llm_answer:
The conflict is framed as a moral duel between the settlement’s two dominant spirits.  
Brindle Bill embodies the “degrade” party—idle, boastful, a card-sharp who lives off others—while Don Carlo, though silent, is the “improve” party’s spirit: he alone pays every wood-yard expense while Dan, his partner, squanders the receipts with Brindle Bill.  

When Don finally demands the money taken from the last sale, Brindle Bill answers with his fists.  
No seconds, no words: Don steps out alone and fights the acknowledged bully bare-handed.  
The brute force of Brindle Bill meets Don’s “true pluck”; a bloody blow from Don evens the fight and breaks the fear that had protected the bully.  

At that instant Simon’s wife—leader of the “improve” faction—lights the cane pile; the blaze drives the whole crowd into the open, ends the fight, and leaves Don in possession of the cash.  
Brindle Bill’s “appeals for fair play” are ignored; the settlement sees that the tyrant can be beaten.  

From that night on the story calls Don “the Hero of Shirt-Tail Bend”: the quiet wood-yard partner who, by standing up single-handed to Brindle Bill and taking back the money that represented the settlement’s future, turned the tide from degradation to possible improvement.
